mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, George Washington to Miss Kitty Livingston, 1778 March 18
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Washington, George, 1732-1799
mdRecord.dcterms:description: From his camp at Valley Forge, George Washington honored a request made by Catharine Wilhelmina Livingston by sending a lock of his hair to her enclosed in this letter. Catharine, known as "Kitty", was the daughter of William Livingston, the governor of New Jersey and a personal friend of George Washington. Dated March 18, 1778, this letter says, "General Washington having been informed, lately, of the honor done him by Miss Kitty Livingston in wishing for a lock of his Hair, takes the liberty of inclosing one, accompanied by his most respectful compliments." Autograph letter signed, 1 page, integral cover, red seal, mounted on paper, watermark (crown over powder horn & LVG), docketed "Geo. Washington to Miss Kitty W. Livingston Camp Valley Forge 18 March 1778". Name on original manuscript appears "G. Washington". Presents her with a lock of hair. Kitty was a daughter of New Jersey's governor.
